panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). Percent of CPU time doing work (not idle). Example: 80% means ~0.8 core busy on a 1-core scale.
panels.title: CPU usage (%) — VM

panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). RAM in use out of total (MemTotal - MemAvailable). Example: 25% = plenty of free memory.
panels.title: Memory used (%) — VM

panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). Disk space used on /. Example: 80% = time to clean up.
panels.title: Root FS used (%) — VM (/)

panels.description: Scope: VM services. Blackbox HTTP checks from Prometheus. 1 = Up, 0 = Down. Example: If Grafana returns non-200, this shows 0.
panels.title: Service uptime (HTTP 200)

panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). Percent of CPU time doing work (not idle). Example: 80% means ~0.8 core busy on a 1-core scale.
panels.title: CPU usage (%) — VM

panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). Percent of CPU time stalled waiting on disk/network. Example: sustained >20% usually means storage bottleneck.
panels.title: CPU I/O wait (%) — VM

panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). How busy each block device is. Example: ~100% = device saturated.
panels.title: Disk busy by device (%) — VM

panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). RAM in use out of total (MemTotal - MemAvailable). Example: 25% = plenty of free memory.
panels.title: Memory used (%) — VM

panels.description: Scope: VM (Ubuntu guest). Disk space used on /. Example: 80% = time to clean up.
panels.title: Root FS used (%) — VM (/)

panels.description: Scope: Containers (cAdvisor). Per-container CPU over 5m. Example: 200% = using ~2 full cores.
panels.title: Container CPU — Top 5 (% of one core)

panels.description: Scope: Containers (cAdvisor). Working set (what the container is actively using).
panels.title: Container Memory — Top 5

panels.description: Scope: Containers (cAdvisor). Write throughput per container.
panels.title: Container Disk Write — Top 5 (bytes/s)

panels.description: Scope: Containers (cAdvisor). Read throughput per container.
panels.title: Container Disk Read — Top 5 (bytes/s)

panels.description: Scope: Containers (cAdvisor). Network transmit rate.
panels.title: Container Net Out — Top 5 (bytes/s)

panels.description: Scope: Containers (cAdvisor). Network receive rate.
panels.title: Container Net In — Top 5 (bytes/s)
Container CPU — Top 10 (% of one core)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Top 10 containers by memory (RAM) usage
**Technical:** Working set memory (actively used RAM) in Mebibytes (MiB). 1024 MiB = 1 GiB.
**What to look for:** Steady increases may indicate memory leaks.
**When to act:** If a container exceeds expected limits or grows continuously.

panels.title: Container Memory — Top 10 (MiB)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Top 10 containers writing to disk
**Technical:** Bytes written per second to filesystem over 5 minutes.
**What to look for:** High writes from unexpected containers. Immich ML writes when processing photos.
**When to act:** Unexpected high writes could indicate logging issues or runaway processes.

panels.title: Container Disk Writes — Top 10 (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Top 10 containers reading from disk
**Technical:** Bytes read per second from filesystem over 5 minutes.
**What to look for:** High reads during media serving (Plex) or photo processing (Immich).
**When to act:** Sustained high reads with slow performance may indicate disk bottleneck (check 'Disk busy' panel).

panels.title: Container Disk Reads — Top 10 (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Top 10 containers by disk write operations
**Technical:** I/O Operations Per Second (IOPS) for writes. Each file operation counts as one IOPS.
**What to look for:** Many small writes vs few large writes. Databases typically have high IOPS.
**When to act:** Very high IOPS (>1000) with slow disk may need optimization.

panels.title: Container Write IOPS — Top 10
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Top 10 containers by disk read operations
**Technical:** I/O Operations Per Second (IOPS) for reads. Number of read requests, not bytes.
**What to look for:** Applications scanning many files will have high read IOPS.
**When to act:** If IOPS is high but throughput (bytes/s) is low, many small files are being accessed.

panels.title: Container Read IOPS — Top 10
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Top 10 containers by network data received
**Technical:** Bytes per second coming into the container over the network.
**What to look for:** File uploads, API requests, downloads. Immich shows spikes during photo uploads.
**When to act:** Unexpected network traffic could indicate compromise or misconfiguration.

panels.title: Container Net RX — Top 10 (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Top 10 containers by network data sent
**Technical:** Bytes per second sent out from the container over the network.
**What to look for:** Media streaming (Plex), photo serving (Immich), API responses.
**When to act:** Sustained unexpected outbound traffic warrants investigation.

panels.title: Container Net TX — Top 10 (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** How many times each container restarted in the last 24 hours
**Technical:** Count of container restart events based on start time changes.
**What to look for:** Zero is healthy. Any number >0 indicates restarts (crashes or manual).
**When to act:** Any unexpected restarts should be investigated via logs.

panels.title: Container Restarts — Last 24h
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** How long each container has been running
**Technical:** Seconds since container started. Time since last restart.
**What to look for:** Low values indicate recent restart. High values show stability.
**When to act:** Use for correlating issues with restart times.

panels.title: Container Uptime (seconds)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Plex main process CPU usage
**Technical:** CPU percentage for the Plex Media Server process. 100% = one full core.
**What to look for:** Spikes when scanning libraries or generating thumbnails.
**When to act:** Sustained high CPU with no active tasks may indicate stuck scan.

panels.title: Immich ML CPU — Process (% of one core)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Immich server process CPU usage
**Technical:** CPU % for Immich web server handling API requests and serving photos.
**What to look for:** Spikes during photo uploads or browsing. Generally low at idle.
**When to act:** High CPU with slow UI indicates performance bottleneck.

panels.title: Plex Metadata Writes — Process (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Immich machine learning process CPU usage
**Technical:** CPU % for Immich ML service (face detection, object recognition, CLIP embeddings).
**What to look for:** High during photo processing jobs. Should be idle when queue is empty.
**When to act:** Sustained high CPU with no jobs may indicate stuck processing.

panels.title: Immich ML Memory — Process (MiB)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Number of threads in Immich ML process
**Technical:** Thread count for ML processing workers.
**What to look for:** Increases with active processing jobs.
**When to act:** Use for troubleshooting stuck jobs or performance tuning.

panels.title: Immich ML Threads — Process
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Intel GPU 3D/rendering workload
**Technical:** Percent of time the GPU render engine is busy (3D graphics, compute).
**What to look for:** Activity during hardware transcoding or ML inference.
**When to act:** Always at 100% may indicate GPU bottleneck.

panels.title: Plex CPU — Process (% of one core)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Plex metadata write throughput
**Technical:** Bytes per second written to disk by Plex for metadata (thumbnails, database updates).
**What to look for:** Activity during library scans or new content addition.
**When to act:** Continuous writes with no scanning may indicate database issues.

panels.title: Immich Server CPU — Process (% of one core)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Plex process memory usage
**Technical:** RAM used by Plex process in Mebibytes.
**What to look for:** Increases with library size. Typical: 500 MiB - 2 GiB.
**When to act:** Continuous growth may indicate memory leak; restart Plex.

panels.title: Plex Memory — Process (MiB)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Number of threads in Plex process
**Technical:** Thread count (lightweight processes within Plex).
**What to look for:** Higher during active transcoding or scanning. Typical: 20-100.
**When to act:** Extremely high (>500) may indicate issue.

panels.title: Plex Metadata Writes — Process (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Immich machine learning process CPU usage
**Technical:** CPU % for Immich ML service (face detection, object recognition, CLIP embeddings).
**What to look for:** High during photo processing jobs. Should be idle when queue is empty.
**When to act:** Sustained high CPU with no jobs may indicate stuck processing.

panels.title: Plex Transcoder CPU (% of one core)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Plex transcoder disk read rate
**Technical:** Bytes per second read from disk by transcoding processes (source video files).
**What to look for:** Activity during active transcodes. Depends on video bitrate.
**When to act:** Low throughput with buffering may indicate disk bottleneck.

panels.title: Plex Transcoder Read (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Plex transcoder disk write rate
**Technical:** Bytes per second written to disk (temp transcoded segments).
**What to look for:** Activity during transcoding. Usually lower than read rate due to compression.
**When to act:** Very high writes may fill up /tmp; configure transcode directory properly.

panels.title: Plex Transcoder Write (bytes/s)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Number of active Plex transcoder processes
**Technical:** Count of running transcoding jobs (one per stream being transcoded).
**What to look for:** 0 = no transcoding, 1+ = active streams needing transcoding.
**When to act:** Many concurrent transcodes strain CPU/GPU; consider limiting or upgrading hardware.

panels.title: iGPU Render Busy (%)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Intel GPU video decoding workload
**Technical:** Percent of time the GPU video decoder is busy.
**What to look for:** Spikes during video transcoding in Plex or Immich video processing.
**When to act:** High during playback indicates hardware acceleration is working.

panels.title: iGPU Video Busy (%)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Intel GPU video enhancement workload
**Technical:** Video post-processing engine usage (upscaling, tone mapping).
**What to look for:** Activity during high-quality transcoding or video enhancement features.
**When to act:** Feature-specific; not all workloads use this engine.

panels.title: iGPU Video Enhance (%)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Intel GPU clock speed
**Technical:** Current GPU frequency in Hertz (Hz). Higher = faster.
**What to look for:** Scales up under load, drops when idle for power saving.
**When to act:** Always low during heavy tasks may indicate power/thermal throttling.

panels.title: iGPU Frequency (Hz)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Intel GPU power consumption
**Technical:** Watts (W) consumed by the integrated GPU.
**What to look for:** Increases with GPU usage. Typical: 2-15W.
**When to act:** Useful for power budget planning; not usually actionable.

panels.title: iGPU GPU Power (W)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Intel GPU idle state residency
**Technical:** RC6 = deepest GPU sleep state. 100% = fully idle, 0% = fully active.
**What to look for:** High % when GPU not in use indicates proper power management.
**When to act:** Always 0% may indicate driver/power management issue.

panels.title: iGPU RC6 Residency (%)
panels.description:
**Quick Summary:** Plex transcoder CPU usage
**Technical:** CPU % used by active transcoding processes (format conversion for playback).
**What to look for:** Spikes during video streaming with transcoding. Idle when no transcodes.
**When to act:** High CPU means transcoding; consider hardware acceleration or pre-converting files.
Reference guide for understanding the metrics in this dashboard

options.content:
**Scopes:**
- Panels labeled **VM** reflect the Ubuntu VM (via node-exporter).
- Panels labeled **Containers** reflect Docker containers (via cAdvisor).

**Tips:**
- **CPU I/O wait:** sustained >20% ⇒ storage is the bottleneck.
- **Disk busy:** near 100% on a device ⇒ saturated; expect slowdowns.
- **Container CPU %:** 100% ≈ one full CPU core.
- **Working set memory:** what a container actively keeps in RAM.

panels.title: How to read this dashboard
